core: 1 Describe the use of rulers and measuring cylinders to find a length or a volume [1]
2 Describe how to measure a variety of time intervals using clocks and digital timers [1]
3 Determine an average value for a small distance and for a short interval of time by measuring multiples (including the period of oscillation of a pendulum) [1]
supplement: 4 Understand that a scalar quantity has magnitude (size) only and that a vector quantity has magnitude and direction [2]
5 Know that the following quantities are scalars: distance, speed, time, mass, energy and temperature [2]
6 Know that the following quantities are vectors: force, weight, velocity, acceleration, momentum, electric field strength and gravitational field strength [2]
7 Determine, by calculation or graphically, the resultant of two vectors at right angles, limited to forces or velocities only [2]

core: 1 Define speed as distance travelled per unit time; recall and use the equation v = s/t [3]
2 Define velocity as speed in a given direction [3]
3 Recall and use the equation average speed = total distance travelled / total time taken [3]
4 Sketch, plot and interpret distance–time and speed–time graphs [3]

5 Determine, qualitatively, from given data or the shape of a distance–time graph or speed–time graph when an object is: (a) at rest (b) moving with constant speed (c) accelerating (d) decelerating [3]
6 Calculate speed from the gradient of a straight-line section of a distance–time graph [4]
7 Calculate the area under a speed–time graph to determine the distance travelled for motion with constant speed or constant acceleration [4]
8 State that the acceleration of free fall g for an object near to the surface of the Earth is approximately constant and is approximately 9.8 m/s² [4]
supplement: 9 Define acceleration as change in velocity per unit time; recall and use the equation a = Δv / Δt [4]
10 Determine from given data or the shape of a speed–time graph when an object is moving with: (a) constant acceleration (b) changing acceleration [4, 5]
11 Calculate acceleration from the gradient of a speed–time graph [5]
12 Know that a deceleration is a negative acceleration and use this in calculations [5]
13 Describe the motion of objects falling in a uniform gravitational field with and without air/liquid resistance, including reference to terminal velocity [5]

core: 1 State that mass is a measure of the quantity of matter in an object at rest relative to the observer [5]
2 State that weight is a gravitational force on an object that has mass [5]
3 Define gravitational field strength as force per unit mass; recall and use the equation g = W/m and know that this is equivalent to the acceleration of free fall [6]
4 Know that weights (and masses) may be compared using a balance [6]
supplement: 5 Describe, and use the concept of, weight as the effect of a gravitational field on a mass [6]

core: 1 Define density as mass per unit volume; recall and use the equation ρ = m/V [6]

2 Describe how to determine the density of a liquid, of a regularly shaped solid and of an irregularly shaped solid which sinks in a liquid (volume by displacement), including appropriate calculations [6]
3 Determine whether an object floats based on density data [7]
supplement: 4 Determine whether one liquid will float on another liquid based on density data given that the liquids do not mix [7]

core: 1 Know that forces may produce changes in the size and shape of an object [7]
2 Sketch, plot and interpret load–extension graphs for an elastic solid and describe the associated experimental procedures [7]
3 Determine the resultant of two or more forces acting along the same straight line [7]
4 Know that an object either remains at rest or continues in a straight line at constant speed unless acted on by a resultant force [8]
5 State that a resultant force may change the velocity of an object by changing its direction of motion or its speed [8]
6 Describe solid friction as the force between two surfaces that may impede motion and produce heating [9]
7 Know that friction (drag) acts on an object moving through a liquid [9]
8 Know that friction (drag) acts on an object moving through a gas (e.g. air resistance) [9]
supplement: 9 Define the spring constant as force per unit extension; recall and use the equation k = F/x [8]
10 Define and use the term 'limit of proportionality' for a load–extension graph and identify this point on the graph [8]
11 Recall and use the equation F = ma and know that the force and the acceleration are in the same direction [10]
12 Describe, qualitatively, motion in a circular path due to a force perpendicular to the motion [10]

core: 1 Describe the moment of a force as a measure of its turning effect and give everyday examples [9]
2 Define the moment of a force as moment = force × perpendicular distance from the pivot; recall and use the equation [9]
3 Apply the principle of moments to situations with one force each side of the pivot, including balancing of a beam [11]
4 State that, when there is no resultant force and no resultant moment, an object is in equilibrium [11]
supplement: 5 Apply the principle of moments to other situations, including those with more than one force each side of the pivot [11]
6 Describe an experiment to demonstrate that there is no resultant moment on an object in equilibrium [11]

core: 1 State what is meant by centre of gravity [11]
2 Describe an experiment to determine the position of the centre of gravity of an irregularly shaped plane lamina [12]
3 Describe, qualitatively, the effect of the position of the centre of gravity on the stability of simple objects [12]

supplement: 1 Define momentum as mass × velocity; recall and use the equation p = mv [12]
2 Define impulse as force × time for which force acts; recall and use the equation impulse = FΔt = Δ(mv) [12]
3 Apply the principle of the conservation of momentum to solve simple problems in one dimension [12]
4 Define resultant force as the change in momentum per unit time; recall and use the equation F = Δp / Δt [13]

core: 1 State that energy may be stored as kinetic, gravitational potential, chemical, elastic (strain), nuclear, electrostatic and internal (thermal) [13]
2 Describe how energy is transferred between stores during events and processes [13]
3 Know the principle of the conservation of energy and apply this principle to simple examples [14]
supplement: 4 Recall and use the equation for kinetic energy Ek = 1/2 mv² [14]
5 Recall and use the equation for the change in gravitational potential energy ΔEp = mgΔh [14]
6 Know the principle of the conservation of energy and apply this principle to complex examples involving multiple stages, including the interpretation of Sankey diagrams [14]

core: 1 Understand that mechanical or electrical work done is equal to the energy transferred [15]
2 Recall and use the equation for mechanical working W = Fd = ΔE [15]
1 Describe how useful energy may be obtained, or electrical power generated, from various resources (fossil fuels, biofuels, water, geothermal, nuclear, solar, wind) [15, 16]
2 Describe advantages and disadvantages of each method in terms of renewability, availability, reliability, scale and environmental impact [16]
3 Understand, qualitatively, the concept of efficiency of energy transfer [16]
supplement: 4 Know that radiation from the Sun is the main source of energy for all our energy resources except geothermal, nuclear and tidal [17]
5 Know that energy is released by nuclear fusion in the Sun [17]
6 Know that research is being carried out to investigate how energy released by nuclear fusion can be used to produce electrical energy on a large scale [17]
7 Define efficiency using equations for energy or power output/input [17]

core: 1 Define power as work done per unit time and also as energy transferred per unit time; recall and use P = W/t and P = ΔE/t [18]
1 Define pressure as force per unit area; recall and use the equation p = F/A [18]
2 Describe how pressure varies with force and area in the context of everyday examples [18]
3 Describe, qualitatively, how the pressure beneath the surface of a liquid changes with depth and density of the liquid [18]
supplement: 4 Recall and use the equation for the change in pressure beneath the surface of a liquid Δp = ρgΔh [19]
